entry.title: insert-sort
entry.content:
Insertion Sort

This sort selects the element after the already sorted and compares them to the AS. Smaller than one of AS = switch.

entry.title: Selection Sort
entry.content:
Selection Sort

This sort selects the smallest element in array and puts it at the front.

entry.title: Bubble Sort
entry.content:
Bubble Sort

This sort compares elements one by one and switches them, “bubbling” the smallest elements to the front.

entry.title: Java Arrays
entry.content:
Java Arrays Intro

What Are Arrays?

Arrays are a basic part of Java code. They are lists of ‘things’ of any data type. Lots of programmers, even the best ones, use arrays a lot. For example, if you want to keep a list of what you need to do before you go out to play:

Do Homework
Clean Your Room
Fold the Landry
Feed the Dog
Wash Your Dirty clothes

You’ll need to create several strings to hold all of the things to do. What a mess! Enter arrays. They can conviently keep your things to do list in one line of code. So the same list of things to do but with an array:

Remember that arrays need a square bracket after their stated data type.

Also remember that when directly defining all of the array values in one line of code, use curly brackets or else your code will blow up.

Playing With Arrays

Finding the smallest value of an array

You can do a lot with arrays, such as reversing them (coming up later!) and changing a value of something in an array. But something that many a programmer asks is, ‘How to find the smallest number in an array?’. Let’s take a look at a program that does just that.

Remember all indexes start with 0, which is why the for loop runs arr.length - 1 instead of arr.length because length returns length.

Finding the largest value of an array

Almost the same as the smallest number program.

reversing arrays

reversing string arrays
